channel.title: 纽约时报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Nikole Hannah-Jones, the leader of The Times’s 1619 Project, was granted tenure by the University of North Carolina after a weekslong dispute. https://t.co/BTJHUjHbsd
With the spread of the highly infectious Delta variant, the WHO and Los Angeles County warned that even vaccinated people should wear masks indoors. https://t.co/X4q73Xk957
Breaking News: Donald Rumsfeld is dead at 88. The secretary of defense for two presidents, he was in charge of the invasion of Iraq under George W. Bush. https://t.co/9bds0sL5i9

Americans will be allowed to declare their self-identified gender on their U.S. passports without providing medical documentation under a new State Department rule that officials said would be announced on Wednesday. https://t.co/Al4G66Ioga

Bill Cosby's case was one of the first high-profile sexual assault trials to unfold in the aftermath of #MeToo, and many considered his conviction a sign that going forward, women's experiences could be afforded greater weight and credibility by jurors. https://t.co/UyDpqZEeWm https://t.co/BnXloYMpES

Breaking News: Bill Cosby will be freed from prison and his sexual assault conviction overturned after the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled that he had been denied a fair trial in 2018. He's served three years of a three-to-10 year prison sentence. https://t.co/ScSWZVXFnr

For some, Jan. 6 was just a rally for their president. For others, it was more.
The New York Times spent months collecting and analyzing footage from the Capitol riot. We scoured radio communications. We interviewed witnesses. Here’s what we found. https://t.co/0EQ2JilQgN

Yale School of Drama, one of the most prestigious programs in the U.S., plans to stop charging tuition after receiving a $150 million gift from the billionaire David Geffen.
It is the largest gift in American theater history, Yale said. https://t.co/YeFlrmLJs8

Children are taught to identify traitors. Neighbors are urged to report one another. Officials are pressed to pledge their loyalty.
One year after it imposed a national security law, China has remade Hong Kong. This is how the city’s freedom was taken. https://t.co/zyIRIFvNad
“Hamilton," the biggest Broadway hit in years, is getting $30 million in relief from the federal government, with the possibility of another $20 million on the way. https://t.co/ods86TbqFb
Loose Earl Grey tea stirred into buttery batter adds a sweet, floral essence that’s subtle but lovely. A little dark chocolate and orange zest makes this cake extra special. https://t.co/g7JiQr4cvK
Los Angeles County is now strongly recommending that everyone wear masks indoors, regardless of vaccination status, as a precaution against the Delta variant. https://t.co/1YkRI9fo9w

People poured into the streets of Mekelle, Ethiopia just after dawn on Tuesday, cheering and weeping with relief after fighters retook the city from government forces that had occupied the region for months and unleashed atrocities. https://t.co/ULahI0yF3a https://t.co/JgvkYoA9tU

In Opinion
"The mRNA vaccines, made by Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech, will likely get full approval for use from the Food and Drug Administration soon, which may be necessary for broader vaccine mandates," writes Aaron Carroll in a guest essay. https://t.co/96lpoJ7VhO

Rep. James Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina and the highest-ranking Black member of Congress, took a rare step into a party primary to endorse the leading opponent of Nina Turner, who is an outspoken ally of Senator Bernie Sanders. https://t.co/aUIwHdUxIp
How unusual is the heat that’s been smothering the Pacific Northwest? Off the charts. https://t.co/R0atewMMis https://t.co/W0xBLM1WRT

"Trying to shield young people from guilt prevents them from seeing history for what it was," Timothy Snyder writes in @NYTMag. The totalitarianism scholar argues how new laws against discussion of race in schools have dire results for American democracy. https://t.co/BIeWtJZFWL
Jacob Zuma, South Africa’s ex-leader and a comrade of Nelson Mandela, was sentenced to prison for refusing to cooperate with a corruption inquiry. https://t.co/N4hF3GttKo

England had not beaten Germany in a knockout game at a major soccer tournament since the 1966 World Cup final, the team’s crowning moment. Now that it has, 2-0 in Euro 2020, history no longer matters, writes @RorySmith. https://t.co/hzL0yiTYWb

Residents of Mekelle, the capital of Ethiopia’s Tigray region, celebrated in the streets after rebel fighters retook the city from government forces and their allies. It was a dramatic turn in the eight-month civil war. https://t.co/XbcjFCdQQ0 https://t.co/cJMfDPXuFk

Jill Biden, the first lady, will appear on the cover of the August issue of Vogue, continuing a tradition that Anna Wintour, the magazine’s editor, had paused during the Trump presidency. https://t.co/7x5YdqshBk

Miami Beach canceled its Independence Day fireworks out of respect for the victims of the collapsed condo building in the nearby town of Surfside.
The city's annual celebration had been set to take place about a mile from the site of the collapse. https://t.co/tH4H9gkSGJ

The 1921 Tulsa race massacre wasn't the only episode of violence overlooked by historians. U.S. institutions are confronting events like the 1919 Elaine massacre for the first time, even as some states try to limit how racism is discussed in schools. https://t.co/CunuhGhmlJ

The WHO has urged even fully vaccinated people to continue wearing masks and taking other precautions because of concerns about the Delta variant. The guidance is a break with the CDC, which relaxed advice on mask-wearing for vaccinated Americans. https://t.co/s7QmUpOt4o

The WHO has urged even fully vaccinated people to continue wearing masks and taking other precautions because of concerns about the Delta variant. The guidance is a break with the CDC, which relaxed advice on mask-wearing for vaccinated Americans. https://t.co/wu8kmkfXWO

Breaking News: Less than three months before the collapse of a condo near Miami, the president of the building’s board warned that structural damage had “gotten significantly worse” since it was highlighted in a 2018 inspection. https://t.co/x6OVBgMAb9
See the moment when a Tour de France spectator caused a pileup after a German rider, Tony Martin, hit a sign they were holding on the side of the road. https://t.co/sdPmfVjvj6 https://t.co/nXCG2Eb1Xb

Alarms blared across an intensive care unit in Delhi, India. Over two dozen Covid patients on ventilators couldn’t breathe. Staff members did all they could, but it wasn’t enough — the hospital had run out of oxygen. Within seven hours, 21 people died. https://t.co/8FHLjqF5oA

By 2031, you may be able to spot the largest comet ever seen.
The last time it was here, modern humans had yet to evolve. The next time it comes around, who can say what will have come of our species. This may be the only chance we will get to see it. https://t.co/pXuX2TntPZ

In Opinion
“Closed-mindedness and ignorance have become core conservative values,” Paul Krugman writes, “and those who reject these values are the enemy, no matter what they may have done to serve the country.” https://t.co/SPFnqxZRw1

The WHO has urged even fully vaccinated people to continue wearing masks and taking other precautions because of concerns about the Delta variant. The guidance is a break with the CDC, which relaxed advice on mask-wearing for vaccinated Americans. https://t.co/ToBpcjuPMi

Breaking News: South Africa’s highest court ordered the imprisonment of Jacob Zuma, the country’s former president, for 15 months on contempt charges, after he defied an order to appear before a corruption inquiry. https://t.co/3BaxCGaxD0

Three scientific studies released on Monday offered fresh evidence that widely used vaccines will continue to protect people against the coronavirus for long periods, possibly for years. https://t.co/pllVlRAed0

Our photographer worked with migrants in Mexico to create a series of self-portraits as they waited to cross the border into the U.S. Here are their stories. https://t.co/V9gz7Lh2dD https://t.co/DA0ewDRm5E
See the moment when a Tour de France spectator caused a pileup after a German rider, Tony Martin, hit a sign they were holding on the side of the road. https://t.co/WxBXsGW2Jy https://t.co/dJxEjF8Pt1

California will ban state-funded travel to Arkansas, Florida, Montana, North Dakota and West Virginia in response to anti-LGBTQ legislation in those places, officials announced on Monday. There are now 17 states under California’s ban. https://t.co/m8z8necebw

Bryce Dershem was less than a minute into his valedictorian speech about his queer identity when the principal appeared to turn off his microphone and take away his prepared remarks. So he recited the speech from memory. https://t.co/oWnlbuoa0R https://t.co/hwb49ZoThe
The bottom of a 13-story condo tower outside Miami has emerged as a possible failure point, according to experts who examined footage of the collapse. https://t.co/3q5YpS1KHe

A huge fire broke out near a major train station in London. It took about 100 firefighters two hours to bring the blaze under control. The police said the explosion was not related to terrorism. https://t.co/yx91MTkRmV https://t.co/4EpB70ZIEJ
“‘Jeopardy!’ is a cultural touchstone, and for a Black man to occupy that podium is significant.” https://t.co/0pwxzTHwI2

“‘Jeopardy!’ is a cultural touchstone, and for a Black man to occupy that podium is significant.” Read @nytmag’s interview with LeVar Burton, who will guest-host the show in late July. https://t.co/m8hY8tIkMW

One year ago, Hong Kong's freedoms were diminished with a sweeping national security law. Since then, activists and journalists have been arrested, assets seized and school curriculums rewritten. But this clampdown on democracy was years in the making. https://t.co/aLw6w1vgvX

Gwen Berry, a track and field athlete, turned from the U.S. flag when she was on the podium at the Olympic trials and the national anthem began to play.
“I feel like it was a setup,” Berry, who has spoken out against systemic racism, said of the timing. https://t.co/y1DxUB8sUL

Gwen Berry, who has used her platform to speak out against systemic racism, turned away from the flag while the national anthem played during the medal ceremony for the U.S. track and field Olympic trials on Saturday. https://t.co/3TPig28d01 https://t.co/j7k7ITuLSw
Mixing Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines can provide strong protection against Covid-19, early results from a British study suggest. https://t.co/B3d3TDwrra

“Racism is a largely invisible force that pervades our society.” The graves of enslaved people who were forced to work on Louisana’s plantations 200 years ago have been hard to find, until now. https://t.co/tV9fkp9mGN https://t.co/tX2JVq6PRx

A third dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine generated a strong immune response to the coronavirus, a study of clinical trial volunteers found.
The research indicates that the shot could be used to extend immunity. https://t.co/Sgru4Lgotk

Surveillance video captures the collapse of a 13-story condo tower outside Miami last week, showing how the southern side of the structure crumbles. Watch our annotated video. https://t.co/HZNZz1XCem https://t.co/7Fhh5DEEOB

Native tribes are experiencing an environmental peril exacerbated by policies — first imposed by white settlers and later the U.S. government — that forced them onto the most undesirable lands. Climate change is now making that marginal land uninhabitable. https://t.co/CuLUiuGaDf

The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna Covid-19 vaccines may protect against the coronavirus for years, a study of more than a dozen vaccinated people found.
The findings add to evidence that most people immunized with the mRNA vaccines may not need boosters. https://t.co/U7eNTP9bvI
